title: Psoriasis Area and Severity Index (PASI)
description: Quantifies the severity of psoriasis by combining assessment of lesion severity and affected body surface area. This standardized measurement tool evaluates four body regions (head, arms, trunk, legs) with scoring for erythema, induration, and desquamation, providing an objective assessment for clinical practice and research.

parameters.name: head_area
parameters.description: Percentage of head/neck area affected by psoriasis

parameters.name: arms_erythema
parameters.description: Erythema (redness) severity in upper limbs/arms region

parameters.name: arms_induration
parameters.description: Induration (thickness) severity in upper limbs/arms region

parameters.name: arms_desquamation
parameters.description: Desquamation (scaling) severity in upper limbs/arms region

parameters.name: arms_area
parameters.description: Percentage of upper limbs/arms area affected by psoriasis

parameters.name: trunk_area
parameters.description: Percentage of trunk area affected by psoriasis

parameters.name: legs_erythema
parameters.description: Erythema (redness) severity in lower limbs/legs region

parameters.name: legs_induration
parameters.description: Induration (thickness) severity in lower limbs/legs region

parameters.name: legs_desquamation
parameters.description: Desquamation (scaling) severity in lower limbs/legs region

parameters.name: legs_area
parameters.description: Percentage of lower limbs/legs area affected by psoriasis

ranges.interpretation: Mild psoriasis with minimal impact. Consider topical therapy, lifestyle modifications, and routine monitoring. Most patients can be managed with topical treatments and supportive care.

Moderate psoriasis requiring active treatment. Consider phototherapy, systemic conventional therapy, or biologic therapy based on patient factors and treatment response. Regular monitoring and adjustment of therapy may be needed.

Severe psoriasis requiring aggressive treatment. Strong consideration for systemic therapy including biologics, immunosuppressants, or phototherapy. May significantly impact quality of life and require multidisciplinary care.

Very severe psoriasis with major impact on quality of life. Requires immediate and aggressive systemic treatment, likely biologics or combination therapy. Consider hospitalization for severe cases. Regular specialist follow-up essential.

notes: Gold standard for psoriasis severity assessment in clinical practice and research
Body surface area weights: Head 0.1, Arms 0.2, Trunk 0.3, Legs 0.4
Total score range: 0-72 points (higher scores indicate more severe disease)
PASI 75 (75% improvement) is considered good therapeutic response
PASI 90 (90% improvement) is considered excellent therapeutic response
PASI 100 indicates complete clearance of psoriasis lesions
Less sensitive for mild psoriasis and localized disease
Requires experienced clinician for consistent scoring
Does not assess nail involvement or quality of life impact
Inter-rater reliability improves with training and experience
Used as primary endpoint in most psoriasis clinical trials
May underestimate disease severity in dark-skinned patients due to erythema assessment
Consider complementary assessments like BSA, PGA, and DLQI for comprehensive evaluation
